TELBIVUDINE

  • Indications and doses
  • Pregnancy
  • Renal impairment
  • Side effects
  • Patient and carer advice
  • National funding/access decisions
  • Cautions
  • Monitoring requirements
  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Chronic hepatitis B infection with compensated liver disease, evidence of viral replication, and histologically documented active liver inflammation or fibrosis, when other treatment is not appropriate,

By mouth

  • For adults
    600 mg once daily.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Manufacturer advises use only if potential benefit outweighs risk.

Advice regarding renal impairment

600 mg every 48 hours if eGFR 30–49 mL/minute/1.73 m2; 600 mg every 72 hours if eGFR less than 30 mL/minute/1.73 m2.

Known side effects

General side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: Abdominal pain, cough, diarrhoea, dizziness, fatigue, headache, nausea, raised serum amylase, raised serum lipase, rash,

uncommon: Arthralgia, myalgia, myopathy (discontinue treatment), peripheral neuropathy, taste disturbance,

rare: Lactic acidosis, rhabdomyolysis,

Advice for patients and carers

Muscle effects and peripheral neuropathy

Patients should be advised to promptly report unexplained muscle pain, tenderness, or weakness, or numbness, tingling or burning sensations.

National funding/access decisions

NICE TA154

Telbivudine for chronic hepatitis B (August 2008)

Telbivudine is not recommended for the treatment of chronic hepatitis B. Patients currently receiving telbivudine can continue treatment until they and their clinician consider it appropriate to stop.

www.nice.org.uk/TA154 www.nice.org.uk/TA154

Cautions regarding administration

  • Lamivudine-resistant chronic hepatitis B—risk of telbivudine resistance

  • Discontinue if deterioration in liver function, hepatic steatosis, progressive hepatomegaly or unexplained lactic acidosis.

Monitoring requirements

Patient parameters

Monitor liver function tests every 3 months and viral markers of hepatitis B every 3–6 months during treatment (continue monitoring for at least 1 year after discontinuation—recurrent hepatitis may occur on discontinuation.

Prepared medicinal forms of TELBIVUDINE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Tablet
